questions.question_text: A financial services company has proprietary trading algorithms, which were created and are maintained by a team of developers on their private source code repository. If the details of this operation became known to competitors, the company's ability to profit from its trading would disappear immediately. Which of the following would the company MOST likely use to protect its trading algorithms?

discussion.content:
MSSP makes the most sense to me.

A. Single-tenancy cloud - The question doesn't mention or allude to needing cloud services.
C. Virtual desktop infrastructure - I think we can agree that a VDI doesn't do much here.
D. Cloud security broker - The question doesn't mention or allude to having/needing cloud services.

B. Managed security service providers - "The core of the MSSP business is providing security monitoring and incident response for an organization’s enterprise networks and endpoints."

https://www.checkpoint.com/cyber-hub/network-security/what-is-a-managed-security-service-provider/

Managed security service providers are best used when organizations do not have the in-house resources to purchase, implement, and manage all of the security functions necessary to protect the business, its data, and its customers.

The proprietary trading algorithm HAS to be kept a secret or the company is toast so Single-tenancy cloud will help. The need for hiring security brokers/providers in not indicated in the question. Only answer the question they ask. There are lots of questions with possible answers that look good "assuming XYZ" but don't make assumptions, stick to what they wrote, that's how multiple choice tests work. Most of the possible answers COULD be right if (insert whatever condition here).

Don't spit into the wind.

questions.question_text: An organization that develops military technology is considering expansion into a foreign country. The organization's owners want to understand the risks associated with such an expansion, and the organization does not want to fund an intensive assessment. Which of the following approaches should be taken?

discussion.content: This is a total softball question. They hand you the answer with "the organization does not want to fund an intensive assessment"

comments.content:
Tabletop exercises are not just for disaster scenarios.

"Tabletop exercises bring together security-minded people and other stakeholders to the table to discuss their roles and ideas for a particular situation such as a security assessment. They may go over things like preferred tools, techniques, targets, and the time and place of assessments." AIO p.367

discussion.content:
Between B (tabletop) and C (compliance) I lean more towards C as I believe tabletop is usually more geared to disaster scenarios and making sure everyone knows what to do.

A compliance assessment is really a gap assessment. You are looking to identify gaps between your existing control environment and what is required. 

A and D are out because they're only talking about it, there's nothing to test.

questions.answer_description:
By deploying a WAF in front of a web application, a shield is placed between the web application and the Internet. While a proxy server protects a client machine's identity by using an intermediary, a WAF is a type of reverse-proxy, protecting the server from exposure by having clients pass through the WAF before reaching the server.
Reference:
https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ddos/glossary/web-application-firewall-waf/
